Award.AwardTitle: Holocene Climate Change in Southwestern Patagonia: New Insights from Large Lake Paleolimnology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project combines climate system modeling and field data collection to examine causes and expressions of Holocene climate change in Southern South America. This is the only significant land mass that extends into the core of the southern westerly wind field, the most energetic wind system on Earth. The project is collects information on past climate change from Lago Sarmiento, a large closed-basin alkaline lake located at 51Â°S. Precipitation in the area, and therefore the hydrology and water balance of the lake, is demonstrably controlled by the intensity of the wind field. Abundant carbonate sediments are present and they precipitate in equilibrium with lake waters. These sediments are analyzed using stable isotope and trace element methods to reconstruct past variations in moisture balance. An excellent chronology can be developed using a combination of AMS radiocarbon, an existing tephrochronology, and U/Th. Lago Sarmiento is located adjacent to Lago del Toro, a similar but open-system lake, as well as a marine fjord of the SW Chilean archipelago. Additional core samples from these systems are being collected and will enable the project to deconvolve the effects of changing temperature, precipitation, and evaporation. The project will use three methods to reconstruct westerly wind variability at this site. The 1st method exploits the strong connection between lake hydrology and oxygen isotope fractionation of biogenic carbonate phases. The 2nd uses carbon isotopes to constrain periods of lake stratification due to reduced wind stress on the lake. The 3rd involves grain size analysis of sediments in areas affected by wind wave-driven redeposition. By combining geochemical & sedimentological methods the project develops high resolution paleoclimate records that provide important information on Holocene climate variability. The study also includes a substantial modeling component, using a General Circulation Model and an embedded high resolution regional climate model to identify climate forcings and feedbacks and for model-data intercomparison.

Broader Impacts and Significance. The project delivers a well-dated Holocene chronology of past variability in rainfall, water balance, and temperature from the Pacific margin of southwestern Patagonia. The record is of high intrinsic value as few high quality climate reconstructions are available from the core of the southern westerly wind field. However, the greatest merit comes from model-data intercomparisons and modeling experiments where the causes of climate change in the SE Pacific over timescales of centuries to millennia are examined. Results aid in climate forecasting for southernmost South America, particularly with regard to water availability. The Holocene westerly wind reconstructions should also provide a useful constraint in climate studies throughout the Southern Ocean. One benefit is likely to be an improved understanding of the capacity of the Southern Ocean to take up anthropogenic carbon dioxide. Benefits to society include greater knowledge of climatic influences on water balance (directly important to farmers, ranchers, & land-use planners in Chile & Argentina) as well as better understanding of how atmospheric flow may be related to global climate change and how it interacts with the ongoing rise in atmospheric CO2 levels. During the project two 1-week workshops for North & South American graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and new faculty members on: 1) Large lake limnology, sedimentology and stratigraphy, & 2) Tools for examining past variability in the hydrologic cycle are being organized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report - Holocene Climate Change in Southwestern Patagonia: New Insights from Large Lake Paleolimnology, NSF Award 1103550, R. Dunbar Stanford University

One of Earth's most prominent atmospheric features is the Southern Hemisphere westerly wind field. The prevailing Southern Hemisphere westerlies circle the globe between about 35? and 65? S. Southernmost South America is the only landmass to extend into the present day core of the wind field. These winds contribute to weather patterns throughout the Southern Hemisphere and are responsible for the majority of moisture transport from the oceans to all the Southern hemisphere continents. Because of the strength of these winds and the large oceanic areas they impact, the southern westerlies are thought to be extremely import for the exchange of atmospheric carbon dioxide with the ocean. Yet, we understand surprisingly little about the variability in strength and latitudinal position of the southern westerlies; most of what we know is from the last thirty years of dispersed and inconsistent weather station observations. Paleoclimate records build our understanding of how the westerlies have behaved on timescales longer than decades. The goal of this project has been to produce a paleoclimate record to improve our understanding of the location and strength of the southern hemisphere westerlies over the last 10,000 years, also known as the Holocene Epoch. The results of our findings supported by NSF Grant 1103550 have been presented at scientific meetings and are included in a number of peer-reviewed publications and news items.

During our project we collected data from southernmost Chilean Patagonia over three field seasons. We collected high-resolution seismic data, water samples, CTD profiles (conductivity, temperature, depth, and dissolved oxygen), sediment grab samples, gravity cores, and piston cores from out research platform, the RV Neecho. We completed water and sediment sampling in Lago Sarmiento, a large, closed-basin lake located in Torres del Paine National Park, and Golfo Almirante Montt. Additionally, we collected high-resolution seismic from Lago del Toro, a large lake adjacent to Lago Sarmiento that may be a rewarding future coring site.

Through this research, we have made significant progress on the understanding of the climate change of southernmost South America during the Holocene Epoch. Furthermore, this study presents new insights into the interaction of wind, precipitation, and global temperature, and the latitudinal position of the southern westerlies. In particular, the westerly winds appear to be more variable during the pre-anthropogenic period of the Holocene that previously thought.

This project has contributed to the education and training of high school, undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students (Alexis Viscaino-Marti, Sverre LeRoy, Alex Stadnyk, Caleb Kruse, Emma Hutchinson, Leena Mathur, Tom Welch, Max Blachman and Samuel Erickson) in research-vessel based field work, the techniques of isotopic and chemical analyses of lacustrine and marine sediment, hydrologic modeling, and techniques and experience of oral, poster, and written communication of their scientific findings. This research comprises the complete dissertation of Sverre LeRoy.
